title: Processing biomass to obtain hydroxylcarboxylic acids

classifications.description: Stationary reactors without moving elements inside
Preparation of carboxylic acid esters by modifying the hydroxylic moiety of the ester, such modification not being an introduction of an ester group
Polyesters derived from hydroxycarboxylic acids or from polycarboxylic acids and polyhydroxy compounds derived from hydroxycarboxylic acids
Esters; Ether-esters of acyclic polycarboxylic acids
Compositions of starch, amylose or amylopectin or of their derivatives or degradation products
Polyesters derived from hydroxycarboxylic acids, e.g. lactones
Lignocellulosic material, e.g. wood, straw or bagasse
Dicarboxylic acids having four or less carbon atoms, e.g. fumaric acid, maleic acid
Stationary reactors without moving elements inside
Pretreatment of cellulosic or lignocellulosic material for subsequent enzymatic treatment or hydrolysis

abstract: Biomass (e.g., plant biomass, animal biomass, and municipal waste biomass) is processed to produce useful intermediates and products, such as hydroxy-carboxylic acids and hydroxy-carboxylic acid derivatives.
claims: 2. The method claim 1, wherein the organism selectively ferments glucose, while xylose is not significantly consumed.
3. The method of claim 1, wherein irradiating is performed with an electron beam.

4. The method of any one of claims 1-3, wherein converting is selected from the group consisting of polymerization, isomerization, esterification, oxidation, reduction, and disproportionation, or combinations thereof.
5. The method of any one of claims 1-4, wherein the product comprises polymers and/or esters.

6. The method of any one of claims 1-5, wherein the sugar solution comprises sucrose, maltose, lactose, mannose, galactose, arabinose, fructose, dimers of these such as cellobiose, heterodimers of these such as sucrose, oligomers of these, and/or mixtures thereof in addition to glucose and/or xylose.

7. The method of claim 6, further comprising purifying the sugar solution comprising a mixture of sugars, optionally utilizing one or more of electrodialysis, distillation, centrifugation, filtration, and cation exchange chromatography.

8. The method of any one of claims 1-7, wherein the hydroxy-carboxylic acid is selected from the group consisting of glycolic acid, lactic acid, malic acid, citric acid and tartaric acid, or optionally, wherein the hydroxyl-carboxylic acid is lactic acid.

9. The method of claim 8, wherein converting comprises polymerizing the lactic acid to a polymer, optionally, wherein the converting comprises polymerizing in a melt without an added solvent, optionally wherein a polymerizing method is selected from the group
      2014256918 05 Apr 2018 consisting of direct condensation of the lactic acid, azeotropic dehydrative condensation of the lactic acid, and dimerizing the lactic acid to lactide followed by ring opening polymerization of the lactide.
10. The method of claim 9, wherein the polymerizing method is direct condensation and includes utilizing coupling agents and/or chain extenders to increase the molecular weight of the polymer.

11. The method of claim 10, wherein the coupling agents and/or chain extenders are selected from the group consisting of triphosgene, carbonyl diimidazole, dicyclohexylcarbodiimide, diisocyanate, acid chlorides, acid anhydrides, epoxides, thiirane, oxazoline, and orthoester, or mixtures thereof.
12. The method of claim 9 wherein the polymerising method is azeotropic condensation.

13. The method of any one of claims 9-12, wherein catalysts and/or promoters are utilized which are selected from the group consisting of Lewis acids, Bronsted acids, H3PO4, H2SO4, methane sulfonic acid, p-toluene sulfonic acid, polymerically supported sulfonic acids, metals, Mg, Al, Ti, Zn, Sn, metal oxides, T1O2, ZnO, GeO2, ZrO2, SnO, SnO2, Sb2O3, metal halides, ZnCh, SnCh, SnCU, Mn(AcO)2, Fe2(LA)3, Co(AcO)2, Ni(AcO)2, Cu(OA)2, Zn(LA)2, Υ(ΟΑ)3, Al(i-PrO)3, Ti(BuO)4, TiO(acac)2, (Bu)2SnO, and Sn(octoate)2, solvates of any of these or mixtures thereof.

14. The method of claims 9 or 13, further comprising conducting at least a portion of the polymerization at a temperature between about 100 and about 200 °C, between about 110 and about 170 °C or between about 120 and about 160 0 C, and/or wherein at least a portion of the polymerization is performed under vacuum, optionally wherein the vacuum is between about 0.1 mm Hg to 300 mm Hg.

15. The method of claim 9, wherein the polymerizing method includes dimerizing the lactic acid to lactide followed by ring opening polymerization of the lactide, optionally wherein the dimerization includes heating the lactic acid to between 100 and 200 °C under a vacuum of about 0.1 to about 100 mmHg, and/or optionally wherein the dimerization includes a catalyst selected from the group consisting of Sn octoate, Li carbonate, Zn diacetate dehydrate, Ti tetraisopropoxide, potassium carbonate, and tin powder or mixtures thereof.
      2014256918 05 Apr 2018

16. The method of claim 15, wherein a ring opening polymerization catalyst is utilized which is selected from the group of Bronsted acids, HBr, HC1, triflic acid, Lewis acids, ZnCh, AICI3, anions, potassium benzoate, potassium phenoxide, potassium t-butoxide, and zinc stearate, metals, Tin, zinc, aluminum, antimony, bismuth, lanthanide and other heavy metals, Tin (II) oxide and tin (II) octoate (e.g., 2-ethylhexanoate), tetraphenyl tin, tin (II) and (IV) halogenides, tin (II) acetylacetonoate, distannoxanes (e.g., hexabutyldistannoxane, R3SnOSnR3 where R groups are alkyl or aryl groups), Al(OiPr)3, other functionalized aluminium alkoxides (e.g., aluminum ethoxide, aluminium methoxide), ethyl zinc, lead (II) oxide, antimony octoate, bismuth octoate, rare earth catalysts, yttrium tris(methyllactate), yttrium tris(2-N-N-dimethylamino ethoxide), samarium tris(2-N-Ndimethylamino ethoxide), yttrium tris(trimethylsilylmethyl), lanthanum tris(2,2,6,6tetramethylheptanedionate), lanthanum tris(acetylacetonate), yttrium octoate, yttrium tris(acetylacetonate), and yttrium tris(2,2,6,6-tetramethylheptanedionate), or mixtures thereof, optionally wherein the mixture is ethyl zinc/aluminum isopropoxide

17. The method of any one of claims 9-16, wherein converting further includes blending the polymer with a second polymer, optionally wherein the second polymer is selected from the group consisting of polyglycols, polyvinyl acetate, polyolefins, styrenic resins, polyacetals, poly(meth)acrylates, polycarbonate, polybutylene succinate, elastomers, polyurethanes, natural rubber, polybutadiene, neoprene, and silicone, or combinations thereof.

18. The method of any one of claims 9-17, wherein a co-monomer is co-polymerized with the lactic acid, optionally wherein the co-monomer is selected from the group consisting of elastomeric units, lactones, glycolic acid, carbonates, morpholinediones, epoxides, 1,4benzodioxepin-2,5-(3H)-dione glycosalicylide, 1,4-benzodioxepin-2,5-(3H, 3-methyl)-dione lactosalicylide, dibenzo-1,5 dioxacin-6-12-dione disalicylide, morpholine-2,5-dione, 1,4dioxane-2,5-dione glycolide, oxepane-2-one ε-caprolactone, l,3-dioxane-2-one trimethylene carconate, 2,2-dimethyltrimethylene carbonate, l,5-dioxepane-2-one, 1,4-dioxane-2-one pdioxanone, gamma-butyrolactone, beta-butyrolactone, beta-me-delta-valerolactone, 1,4dioxane-2,3-dione ethylene oxalate, 3-[benzyloxycarbonyl methyl]-1,4-dioxane-2,5-dione, ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, 5,5'(oxepane-2-one), 2,4,7, 9-tetraoxa-spiro[5,5]undecane3,8-dione, and Spiro-bid-dimethylene caronate, or mixtures thereof.

19. The method of any one of claims 9-18, comprising combining the polymer with fillers, optionally, wherein the filler is selected from the group consisting of silicates, layered
      2014256918 05 Apr 2018 silicates, polymer and organically modified layered silicate, synthetic mica, carbon, carbon fibers, glass fibers, boric acid, talc, montmorillonite, clay, starch, corn starch, wheat starch, cellulose fibers, paper, rayon, non-woven fibers, wood flours, whiskers of potassium titanate, whiskers of aluminum borate, 4,4'-thiodiphenol, and glycerol, or mixtures thereof, and optionally, wherein combining further includes extrusion and/or compression molding.

20. The method of any one of claims 9-19, further comprising branching or cross linking the polymer, optionally, wherein a cross linking agent is utilized to cross link the polymer and the cross-linking agent selected from the group consisting of 5,5'-bis(oxepane-2one)(bis- ε -caprolactone)), spiro-bis-dimethylene carbonate, peroxides, dicumyl peroxide, benzoyl peroxide, unsaturated alcohols, hydroxyethyl methacrylate, 2-butene-l,4-diol, unsaturated anhydrides, maleic anhydride, saturated epoxides, and glycidyl methacrylate, or combinations thereof.

22. The method of any one of claims 9-21, wherein the converting further includes blending the polymer with a plasticizer, optionally, wherein the plasticizer is selected from the group consisting of triacetin, tributyl citrate, polyethylene glycol, acetic acid ester of a monoglycerides, and diethyl bishydroxymethyl malonate or mixtures thereof.

23. A product comprising:
      one or more converted hydroxy-carboxylic acids, wherein the one or more converted hydroxy-carboxylic acid is produced by the selective fermentation of a sugar solution derived from acidic or enzymatic saccharification of an irradiated lignocellulosic or cellulosic material.
24. The product of claim 23, wherein the hydroxy-carboxylic acid is selected from the group consisting of glycolic acid, lactic acid, malic acid, citric acid and tartaric acid.
25. The product of claim 23 or 24, wherein the product is a polymer including one or more of the converted hydroxy-carboxylic acids in the polymer backbone.

26. The product of any one of claim 23-25, further comprising a non-hydroxy carboxyl acid in the polymer backbone, optionally, wherein the hydroxy-carboxylic acid is selected from the group consisting of glycolic acid, lactic acid (e.g., D, L or mixtures of D and L), malic acid, citric acid, tartaric acid, carmine, cyclobutyrol, 3- dehydroquinic acid, diethyl tartrate, 2,3-dihydroxy-3-methylpentanoic acid, 3,4- dihydroxymandelic acid, glyceric acid, homocitric acid, homoisocitric acid, beta- hydroxy beta-methylbutyric acid, 4hydroxy-4-methylpentanoic acid, hydroxybutyric acid, 2-hydroxybutyric acid, betahydroxybutyric acid, gamma-hydroxybutyric acid, alpha-hydroxyglutaric acid, 5hydroxyindoleacetic acid, 3-hydroxyisobutyric acid, 3- hydroxypentanoic acid, 3hydroxypropionic acid, hydroxypyruvic acid, gluconic acid, glucuronic acid, alpha, beta, gamma or delta-hydroxyvaleric acid; isocitric acid, isopropylmalic acid, kynurenic acid, mandelic acid, mevalonic acid, monatin, myriocin, pamoic acid, pantoic acid, prephenic acid, shikimic acid, tartronic acid, threonic acid, tropic acid, vanillylmandelic acid, and xanthurenic acid, or mixtures thereof.

27. The product of any one of claims 22-26, wherein the polymer is cross-linked and/or wherein the polymer is a grafted co-polymer.
      2014256918 05 Apr 2018

28. The method of claim 1, where the electron beam has a total beam power of 100 to 1500 kW, optionally, wherein after irradiation, and before saccharification, the reduced recalcitrance lignocellulosic material is heat treated at a temperature of 95 to 160 °C.

29. The method of claim 1, wherein the organism is selected from the group consisting of Lactobacillus casei, Lactobacillus rhamnosus, Lactobacillus delbrueckii subspecies delbrueckii, Lactobacillus plantarum, Lactobacillus coryniformis subspecies torquens, Lactobacillus pentosus, Lactobacillus brevis, Pediococcus pentosaceus, Rhizopus oryzae, Enterococcus faecalis, Lactobacillus helveticus, Lactobacillus bulgaricus, Lactobacillus casei, and lactobacillus amylophilus, or mixtures thereof, or wherein the organism is selected from the group consisting of Lactobacillus rhamnosus, Lactobacillus coryni/ormis subspecies torquens, Lactobacillus pentosus, and Lactobacillus brevis, or mixtures thereof.

30. The method of claim 1, where prior to irradiation the biomass size is reduced by cutting, grinding, shearing, pulverizing, and/or chopping, optionally wherein the biomass is heat treated at a temperature of 100 to 150 °C, or is heat treated at a temperature of 110 to 140 °C, and optionally wherein the heat treated biomass step comprises an aqueous mixture with the biomass 10 to 90 wt. % of the entire mixture.

31. The method of claim 1 where converting comprises chemically converting, optionally, wherein chemically converting is selected from the group consisting of polymerization, isomerization, esterification, oxidation, reduction, and disproportionation, or combinations thereof.
